Ricardo Garcia Corrêa

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/0918340398960228
  • Última atualização do currículo em 09/01/2015

Possui graduação em Farmácia e Bioquímica pela Faculdade de Ciências Farmacêuticas da Universidade de São Paulo (1993), sendo mestre (1997) e doutor (2001) em Bioquímica pelo Instituto de Química da Universidade de São Paulo. Durante o Doutorado, foi responsável pelo projeto-piloto do Genoma-Câncer (apoiado pelo convênio FAPESP/LICR), sendo o primeiro cientista a descobrir e patentear um novo gene humano (SEMA6B), com potencial de marcador tumoral, no Brasil. Durante o Pós-Doutorado, foi o pioneiro na identificação da via de sinalização NF-kB em zebrafish (peixe paulistinha) e no papel desta via frente a especificação do eixo antero-posterior em vertebrados. Mais recentemente, atua como pesquisador líder na caracterização e validação de um novo gene humano (NWD1) como marcador de câncer de próstata. Tem experiência prática e didática nas áreas de Bioquímica, Biologia Celular e Molecular, Genética, Fisiologia e Morfologia (ênfase em Biologia do Desenvolvimento). Atua principalmente em temas envolvendo genômica, análise funcional de novos genes humanos, vias de transdução de sinal intrínsicas a processos inflamatórios, morte celular e imunidade inata, e a utilização de zebrafish como modelo embriológico. Atualmente é Pesquisador Sênior do Sanford-Burnham Medical Research Institute (CA, USA) e Pesquisador Visitante Especial do Departamento de Bioquímica do Instituto de Química da Universidade de São Paulo. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2015 - Atual
Papel fisiopatológico dos sensores NOD1 e NLRP1 e sua correlação com a embriogênese (Pesquisador Visitante Especial - PVE/CAPES 88881.068070/2014-01)
Descrição: As lacunas que limitam o entendimento de patologias, como o câncer, residem, em grande parte, na melhor caracterização funcional de determinadas vias de sinalização e de genes correlatos no contexto do desenvolvimento humano. Um número crescente de evidências justifica a potencial interface entre a maturação e diferenciação embrionária com a evolução de certas patologias humanas. Estudos genéticos envolvendo modelos inovadores como o zebrafish (peixe paulistinha ) têm sido realizados com o intuito de compreender eventos ligados à embriogênese que possam justificar a evolução de processos patológicos como diabetes, vitiligo e câncer. No presente plano, pretende-se desenvolver uma linha de pesquisa focalizando uma particular família de receptores citossólicos denominados NLRs (NACHT and Leucine Rich Repeat domain containing proteins), cujos estudos recentes evidenciam sua participação consistente e essencial na homeostase e controle da proliferação celular. Propõe-se avaliar a participação e importância de membros da família NLR, particularmente NOD1 e NLRP1, no desenvolvimento de vertebrados e seu paralelo em distúrbios de impacto social como diabetes, câncer de mama e vitiligo. O domínio de ferramentas de superexpressão e knockdown gênico (morfolinos, shRNAs, TALENs, CRISPR/Cas9) auxiliarão no processo de caracterização gênica e sua possível correlação funcional in vivo..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (3) .

Integrantes: Ricardo Garcia Corrêa - Integrante / Mari Cleide Sogayar - Coordenador / Sandro Roberto Marana - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior - Auxílio financeiro.
2013 - 2013
Role of NOD1 (NLRC1) signaling in Diabetes Mellitus (Attraction of Young Talent - BJT/CNPq 400046/2012)
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Mari Cleide Sogayar em 23/09/2018.
Descrição: NOD1 (NLRC1) is a member of the NLR family (NACHT and Leucine Rich Repeat domain containing proteins), mainly integrated by cytosolic bacterial receptors that participate in innate immunity. Despite this protein family being composed of over 20 members in humans, only two of these proteins (dubbed as NOD1 and NOD2) have been well described to act as bacterial sensors that directly converge to the activation of NF-κB signaling pathway, a major cellular cascade involved in pathological events such as inflammation, apoptosis and immune response. Despite the homology in protein structure and downstream signaling involving NOD1 and NOD2, a well-established correlation with disease predisposition has been described mostly for NOD2 and surprisingly, a series of potential NOD1 related diseases has only recently been emerging. In fact, an increasing number of inflammatory diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS), cardiovascular inflammation and insulin resistance have been linked to constitutive activation of NOD1 signaling. In this project, we propose to assess the potential association of NOD1 with pancreatic diseases, focusing Diabetes mellitus as a model, to better understand this subset of disorders and the putative role of this NLR protein in the disease progression..
Situação: Desativado; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Ricardo Garcia Corrêa - Coordenador / Sogayar, M. C. - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico - Auxílio financeiro.
2013 - Atual
Characterization of the novel NLR-related protein NWD1 as a prostate cancer biomarker: functional analysis and mechanisms of action.
Descrição: The intersections between innate immunity and cancer have been investigated for decades, with widespread acceptance that chronic inflammation contributes to the pathogenesis or progression of several types of malignancies. Numerous mediators of the innate immune responses have been connected to tumor risk through genetic, molecular, and cellular analysis. The NACHT and Leucine Rich Repeat domain containing proteins (NLRs) represent a family of innate immunity proteins responsible for pathogen sensing in the cytosol. NLRs activate inflammatory signaling pathways including NF-kB and MAPK, stress kinases, interferon responses factors (IRFs), autophagy, and caspase-dependent cytokine secretion. A growing body of evidence has been associating NLR polymorphisms with several human cancers, however, the precise role of these NLRs in cancer progression is not well defined. We have recently identified a novel NLR-like protein named NWD1, which was previously identified in zebrafish but had not yet been analyzed in humans. We verified that NWD1 expression was very high in human prostate tissue and other parts of the male reproductive system. Strikingly, NWD1 expression was higher than normal in human prostate cancer cell lines, especially in castration-resistant and highly metastatic cell lines. Similarly, NWD1 protein levels were higher than normal in advanced-stage and castration-resistant prostate tumor tissue from patients. We were able to correlate NWD1 function with androgen receptor (AR) signaling but more extensive work needs to be pursued to understand its mechanism of action towards AR and other signaling pathways. A broad range of arrays will be further assessed to strengthen a potential use of NWD1 (at RNA and/or protein levels) as a prostate cancer biomarker. In vivo knockdown and overexpression studies will be our final objective to conclude, as previously observed in cultured androgen-responsive cells, whether NWD1 has a major impact in prostate tumor growth..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Ricardo Garcia Corrêa - Coordenador.
2008 - 2012
High Throughput Screening Assays for NOD1 and NOD2 Inhibitors (NIH R03 MH084844)
Descrição: NOD1 (NLRC1) and NOD2 (NLRC2) are among the most prominent members of the NLR family - proteins that contain nucleotide-binding NACHT domains and receptor-like Leucine Rich Repeat domains. With over 20 members identified in humans, NLRs represent important components of the mammalian innate immune system, serving as intracellular receptors for pathogens and for endogenous molecules elaborated by tissue injury. NOD1 and NOD2 proteins operate as microbial sensors through the recognition of specific peptidoglycan constituents of bacteria. Upon activation, these NLR family members initiate signal transduction mechanisms that include stimulation of NF-κB, stress kinases, interferon responses factors (IRFs), and autophagy. Hereditary polymorphisms in the genes encoding NOD1 and NOD2 have been associated with an increasing number of chronic inflammatory diseases. In fact, potential roles for NOD1 and NOD2 in inflammatory disorders have been revealed by investigations using a series of animal models. Therefore, the objective of this project was to isolate small compounds that inhibit NF-kappaB pathway, specifically through NOD1 and NOD2 signaling cascades, using a primary cell-based assay based on NF-kappaB mediated luciferase reporter read-out. To this end, we engineered a HEK 293T variant cell line stably transduced with luciferase reporter gene and further treated it with NOD1- and NOD2-related inducers (gamma-tri-DAP and muramyl dipeptide, respectively). Blockage of NF-kappaB activation, by the addition of compounds from the NIH library, was monitored as a decrease into luminescence signal. Non-cytotoxic hits (positive compounds) with no inhibitory effects after treatment with non-related NF-kappaB activators (using TNF-alpha as a prototype) would then be considered for secondary assays to possibly nominate NOD-dependent NF-kappaB inhibitors.Chemical inhibitors of these innate immunity proteins will provide powerful research tools for evaluating the roles of NLR family members in host-pathogen responses, inflammatory diseases and autoimmunity, as well as potential leads for further drug development towards NOD-related maladies..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Ricardo Garcia Corrêa - Integrante / John C Reed - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): National Institutes of Health - Auxílio financeiro.
2001 - 2005
Regulation of NF-kB signaling pathway (NIH R01 AI048034)
Descrição: Activation of the NF-κB pathway is involved in a large number of physiological events, like inflammation, immune response, development, cell growth and differentiation. NF-κB activity is induced by a variety of activators (cytokines, stress, pathogens and pharmacological agents) which converge to the recruitment of the serine-specific IκB kinase complex (IKK), leading to the phosphorylation and proteasome-dependent degradation of inhibitory IκB proteins and release of transcriptionally competent NF-κB dimers. Interestingly, NF-kB transcriptional factors are conserved from insects to humans. In Drosophila melanogaster, NF-kB factors (Dorsal, Dif, and Relish) are responsible for regulating several biological functions such as (i) dorsoventral embryonic polarity specification, (ii) humoral immunity, (iii) hemopoiesis, and (iv) muscle development. In fact, the activation of NF-κB pathway via the IKK complex is essential for embryogenesis. Still, the role of IKK1, one of the catalytic subunits of the IKK complex in controlling NF-κB activation is less well understood, since it has kinase-dependent and independent activities, which impinge on NF-κB signaling, in a tissue specific manner. Despite the advances described in chicks and mice, the role of NF-kB in early embryonic processes, such as evolution of the germ layers and morphogenesis, remains uncharacterized. In the proposed project, we utilized zebrafish as a model system to better understand NF-kB regulation during early embryogenesis and how this pathway as well as its major modulators could impact vertebrate development..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Ricardo Garcia Corrêa - Integrante / Vinay Tergaonkar - Integrante / Virginie Bottero - Integrante / Inder M Verma - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): National Institutes of Health - Auxílio financeiro.
1997 - 2001
Generation of expressed sequence tags by RAP-PCR: identification of new genes in human breast cancer model (FAPESP 97/04213-4)
Descrição: The complete sequence of the human genome should be available in a matter of one year. In this context, "expressed sequence tags" (ESTs) will be crucial for the identification of human genes and gene expression analysis. Here we describe a novel approach for generating cDNA libraries using arbitrary primers by PCR, originated from breast cancer mRNA samples. Clones of these libraries were sequenced to generate a total of 6,029 ESTs. Using this approach, we observed a significant normalization of different mRNA sub-populations and preferential amplification towards the central portions of coding genes. Bioinformatics analysis indicates that 3,350 ESTs (56%) have significant similarities to sequences of DNA and /or cDNA already known (annotated) described in different organisms, and 1509 ESTs (25%) did not have any similarity to different databases . Among the annotated sequences, we identified some sequences with high similarity to known genes in different organisms, indicating the discovery of homologous genes possibly involved in carcinogenic processes. As an example, we isolated and partially characterize (i) a novel isoform NABC1 gene (novel amplified sequence in breast carcinoma 1), which is poorly expressed in colorectal tumors and (ii) a novel member of semaphorin family (molecules of axonal motility) which has a low expression in glioblastoma cell lines treated by retinoic acid, an anti-tumor agent. This work serves as a pilot-project and basis for the Cancer Genome Project in Brazil (LICR/FAPESP)..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Ricardo Garcia Corrêa - Integrante / Simpson, A.J. - Integrante / Ricardo Renzo Brentani - Coordenador.


Projetos de desenvolvimento
2006 - 2007
Produção de hormônio folículo-estimulante (FSH) bovino recombinante em células de mamífero (FAPESP 06/53161-8)
Descrição: O presente projeto visa a clonagem dos cDNAs referentes às cadeias alfa e beta do FSH bovino (hormônio de extrema relevância em técnicas de reprodução animal, em especial a transferência de embriões) em vetor de expressão plasmideal e sua transfecção em linhagem de céluals de mamífero, com posterior seleção de clones superprodutores do Hormônio Folículo Estimulante Bovino com alta atividade biológica específica.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Desenvolvimento.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) .

Integrantes: Ricardo Garcia Corrêa - Coordenador / Tatiane Maldonado Coelho - Integrante / Mari Cleide Sogayar - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo - Bolsa.
